freeze.translation[0].definitions[0].def: if a liquid or something wet freezes or is frozen, it becomes hard and solid because the temperature is very cold
freeze.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to preserve food for a long time by keeping it at a very low temperature, or to be preserved in this way
freeze.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: I think I’ll freeze that extra meat.
freeze.translation[0].definitions[2].def: if a machine, engine, pipe etc freezes, the liquid inside it becomes solid with cold, so that it does not work properly
freeze.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: I nearly froze to death watching that football match.
freeze.translation[0].definitions[4].def: if a government or company freezes wages, prices etc, they do not increase them for a period of time
freeze.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: The government has been forced to cut spending and freeze public-sector wages.
freeze.translation[0].definitions[5].def: to legally prevent money in a bank from being spent, property from being sold etc
freeze.translation[0].definitions[6].def: to stop moving suddenly and stay completely still and quiet
freeze.translation[0].definitions[6].exa: I froze and listened; someone was in my apartment.
freeze.translation[0].definitions[7].def: to stop a DVD or video in order to be able to look at a particular part of it
freeze.translation[0].definitions[7].exa: He froze the picture on the screen.
freeze.translation[1].definitions[0].def: a time when people are not allowed to increase prices or pay
freeze.translation[1].definitions[1].def: the stopping of some activity or process
freeze.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: The government have imposed a freeze on civil service appointments.
freeze.translation[1].definitions[2].def: a period of extremely cold weather
freeze.translation[1].definitions[3].def: a short period of time, especially at night, when the temperature is extremely low
freeze.translation[2].definitions[0].def: if a government or company freezes prices, wages etc, they keep them at a particular level
freeze.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: The company cut executive salaries by 10%, all remaining salaries were frozen.
The president froze fuel prices and set a ceiling on prices for basic foodstuffs.
freeze.translation[2].definitions[1].def: to legally prevent money in a bank from being taken out, property from being sold etc, for example because there is a disagreement concerning it
freeze.translation[2].definitions[1].exa: A federal judge froze more than $20 million in FundAmerica bank accounts last Friday after several California investors sued Mr Edwards.
freeze.translation[2].definitions[2].def: to stop an activity or a proposed activity for a period of time
freeze.translation[2].definitions[2].exa: The airline froze hiring and instructed employees to reduce spending.
Mr Smith has frozen plans to develop the record company.
freeze.translation[2].definitions[3].def: if a computer or a computer screen freezes, the image on the screen will not change because of a problem with the computer
freeze.translation[2].definitions[3].exa: My computer froze and I had to reboot it.
freeze.translation[3].definitions[0].def: when prices, wages etc are fixed at a particular level
freeze.translation[3].definitions[0].exa: They said the cable television industry was abusing its market position, and called for a mandatory price freeze in cable rates.
The prime minister called for a pay freeze to help keep inflation down.
freeze.translation[3].definitions[1].def: when an activity is stopped for a period of time
freeze.translation[3].definitions[1].exa: If the government imposes a freeze on the roads programme, up to 20,000 jobs could be lost.
In an effort to reduce overheads, they laid off a quarter of the staff and initiated a hiring freeze (=when a company does not take new employees).
